Post_Title: A quick update to my post about getting a warning for telling my colleague that not all residents in our nursing home deserve a relationship with their kids.
post_text:
[The original post.](https://www.reddit.com/r/raisedbynarcissists/comments/lv1plf/i_got_a_warning_at_the_nursing_home_i_work_at_for/?utm_medium=android_app&utm_source=share)

The woman emailed to complain about my colleague's behavior, saying she was being judgemental and rude. She also thanked me for stepping in and explained she didn't say anything at the time because she was so anxious and stressed about seeing her mother and then being judged on top of that made it hard to speak or stand up for herself. She didn't go into detail into her relationship with her mother, she just said she feels uncomfortable around her and would prefer not to be judged about her unwillingness to see her.

So my supervisor apologized to me but mentioned I should try a slightly more diplomatic way of intervening next time, which is fair. My colleague has been warned not to make judgemental comments in front of residents or family. It won't stop my colleagues talking amongst themselves about how ungrateful or cruel they think some adult children are just for not visiting, but maybe it'll prevent more people from being judged to their face.

Threads.Reply_Text:
That’s my favorite type of conflict resolution: “ok you were 100% right, but try to be more diplomatic next time?”

And it’s always phrased as a question, because management has to say they gave you some sort of constructive criticism when there’s not necessarily a diplomatic way of calling someone on their shit. Good on you, OP!

Replies.Reply_Text: This. As far as I could tell from her last post, she told her colleague like it is. Just because someone is honest doesn’t mean they aren’t diplomatic. It would be different if OP called her colleague names, rolled her eyes, or showed other signs of passive aggressiveness.

Or it could have just been management trying to be fair. Or the coworker felt defensive and said OP’s delivery wasn’t the best. Harassment is one of those buzzwords used by many and HR has to take it seriously if it really was harassment, which in this case, it’s not, because it’s not repeated, unwelcomed behaviors.

Edit: not sure why I was down voted. No where does it say the coworker claimed “harassment.” I’m making just as much of a conclusion and assumption as the person above me. Also, look up what harassment is before you get pissed that I didn’t exactly validate misinformation.
I think another thing to bear in mind is that people with a narcissistic bent sometimes end up in the caregiving occupations because having someone weaker and dependent on them feeds their ego.
Yep! You’re absolutely right about that.

I can understand the difficulties, telling the truth in diplomatic ways. I think I'm screwed up, in what ways I really can't be arsed to diagnose. I tend to be blunt..

Am I screwed up for watching 'nomadland' and wishing I could live like that....
